node.title: How Truman Capote Betrayed His High-Society ‘Swans’
node.alt: Truman Capote with Gloria Vanderbilt (left) and Babe Paley in 1957. Over the years, Capote, so much more captivating than these women’s boorish husbands, had managed to slither his way into their hearts.
node.description: “Capote’s Women,” by Laurence Leamer, recounts the author’s intimate friendships with some of midcentury America’s most glamorous women — and what happened when he decided to depict them in his fiction.
node.content: ["CAPOTE\u2019S WOMENA True Story of Love, Betrayal, and a Swan Song for an EraBy Laurence Leamer", "There\u2019s a poem by Thomas Hardy, \u201cThe Convergence of the Twain,\u201d which chronicles the construction of the Titanic, in all its opulence, and the simultaneous formation of its \u201csinister mate\u201d \u2014 the iceberg that is set to destroy it: \u201cAnd as the smart ship grew / In stature, grace and hue, / In shadowy silent distance grew the iceberg too.\u201d", "This poem came to mind as I read \u201cCapote\u2019s Women,\u201d the story of the high-society women of the 1950s and \u201960s who were befriended, and then betrayed, by Truman Capote, their sinister mate. In frothy prose \u2014 meals are \u201csplendid repasts,\u201d apartments \u201cabodes\u201d \u2014 Laurence Leamer describes this \u201ccoterie of gorgeous, witty and fabulously rich women.\u201d They married well, and often, passing their days buying lunch, clothes and houses.", "Capote called them his \u201cswans.\u201d One of them was the \u201cgorgeous and vivacious\u201d Barbara \u201cBabe\u201d Paley, who \u201cnever left the Best-Dressed List\u201d and created \u201cstunning\u201d homes, \u201cexquisitely decorated.\u201d \u201cStunning\u201d is one of Leamer\u2019s preferred adjectives.", "Another swan was Gloria Guinness, another \u201cregular on the Best-Dressed List.\u201d She underwent three starter marriages \u2014 to the manager of a sugar factory in Veracruz, to a German count and to the son of an Egyptian ambassador \u2014 and enjoyed affairs with, among others, a high-ranking Nazi and the British ambassador to France, before ending up with the banking heir Loel Guinness, who, as luck would have it, had recently been left today\u2019s equivalent of $2.39 billion in his father\u2019s will.", "Other swans included Nancy \u201cSlim\u201d Keith, \u201ca stunning California girl,\u201d Jackie Kennedy\u2019s bitter little sister, Princess Lee Radziwill, and Pamela Harriman, who, despite an \u201cample derri\u00e8re,\u201d remained, at least through Leamer\u2019s eyes, \u201cstunningly attractive.\u201d Leamer helpfully informs us that Pamela \u201cwent nowhere without being exquisitely put together.\u201d", "After an early marriage to Winston Churchill\u2019s drunken son Randolph, Pamela enjoyed flings with men including Jock Whitney, Gen. Frederick Anderson Jr., Prince Aly Khan, Gianni Agnelli (who owned \u201cat least 10 magnificent residences\u201d), a Greek shipping tycoon called Andr\u00e9 Embiricos and Baron Elie de Rothschild. She eventually married Leland Hayward, the former husband of Slim Keith. Five and a half months after his death, she successfully rekindled an old flame, the 79-year-old Averell Harriman. \u201cOnly men of power and substance intrigued her,\u201d Leamer notes.", "The trouble with reading about Capote\u2019s swans, all so fluffy and flighty, is that it soon becomes hard to tell them apart, a struggle further complicated by the increasingly dizzying Venn diagram of their intersecting love affairs.", "Their iceberg loomed in the shape of \u201cAnswered Prayers,\u201d which Capote had surreptitiously announced to his publisher (\u201ca large novel, my magnum opus, a book about which I must be very silent, so as not [to] alarm my \u2018sitters\u2019\u201d) way back in 1958, shortly before the publication of \u201cBreakfast at Tiffany\u2019s.\u201d", "Over the years, Capote, so much more captivating than these women\u2019s boorish husbands, had managed to slither his way into their hearts. Charmed by his attention, they were happy to exchange intimacies of their own for the intimacies of the others.", "Leamer tells of a manicurist who used to work on Paley\u2019s nails while Capote told savage tales about the other swans. When the manicurist went to do the nails of one of the other swans, Truman would once again be there, this time relaying catty tales about Paley.", "The story of how Capote published a hurtful extract from his promised book in Esquire in 1975, his ostracism by the wounded swans and his early death from liver disease, has already been expertly told in biographies by Gerald Clarke and George Plimpton.", "His long-awaited masterpiece never materialized; like so many authors led astray by the blandishments of high society, he had never quite got around to writing it. His publisher called the thin, scrappy manuscript he left behind \u201cunfinished\u201d when it appeared in book form in 1987, but it was closer to \u201cunstarted.\u201d Looked at from another angle, perhaps the swans were the iceberg, and Capote the Titanic."]
